title: CTRL0000061476 - Transcribed Interview of Greg Rubenacker, (April 6, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Zoom, commencing at 2:05 p.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
We will go on the record at 2:05 p.m. eastern time.
This is a transcribed interview of Mr. Greg Rubenacker,
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
United States Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
M r - And can you spell your last name, please?
This will be a staff-led interview.
My name is Greg Thomas Rubenacker.
And members, of course, may choose to also
But in the room with you today is myself,
There are currently no Members of Congress that
At this time, could counsel please state their name for the record?
Michaelangelo Matera, attorney for Mr. Rubenacker.
There is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
that you please wait until each question's completed before you begin your response, and
we will try to wait until your response is complete before we ask the next question.
The stenographer cannot record nonverbal responses, such as shaking your head,
so it's important that you answer each question with an audible, verbal response.
Mr. Rubenacker, if I see you shaking your head, don't worry about it too much.
just indicate it for the record, whether it be a positive or negative response.
We ask that you please provide complete answers based on your best
the answer, please simply say so.
If the question is not clear, just ask for a clarification.
You may only refuse to answer a question to preserve a privilege recognized by
Such privileges include the Fifth Amendment privilege against
First, it's important that you understand this interview today is voluntary.
any time you would like to stop speaking with us, that's your choice.
point you need to discuss something with your attorney in private, please just let us
know, and we'll take a break so you can have that conversation.
Second, this interview is not under oath, but because this is a formal select
committee investigation, you are obligated under Federal law to tell the truth, the same
as if you were speaking to the FBI or the DOJ.
criminal penalties for perjury and/or false statements.
M r - You are also not obligated to keep the fact of this interview and
It is unlawful to deliberately provide false
For this interview, providing false information could result in
You are free to tell whomever you wish that you met with
us, including a prosecutor or a judge on your case, or you can tell no one at all.
Do you understand that as well?
The select committee investigation is separate and independent from DOJ.
have no involvement with the prosecutions, and DOJ is not a partner with the select
The select committee also is not a party to your criminal case and is not agreeing
to submit anything on your behalf to the judge, nor can we make any representation
whether, if you tell judge you met with us, that the judge will be more favorable to you
And, last, we have agreed with your attorney not to share the substance of what
you say with the DOJ prior to your sentencing, but there are two exceptions.
us about evidence of a crime that we thought law enforcement was unaware of or if we
had reason to believe that you lied to us during this interview, then we would be
obligated to tell the DOJ or another appropriate law enforcement agency.
And if you tell the judge that you met with us, please understand that may prompt
questions from the judge about what you said and whether it's consistent with your prior
we may be asked to respond and divulge what you said.
And if the judge starts asking questions,
So, logistically speaking, please let us know if you need any breaks or anything like
that as we go through, and we'll make sure we accommodate your request.
So let's start off with a little bit of your background, Mr. Rubenacker.
tell us a little bit, like, where you're from, how long you've lived there, your educational
I was raised on Long Island.
So my name is Greg Rubenacker.
I've lived there my whole life.
year and a half for marketing.
I went to Nassau Community College for a
I dropped out, and I started pursuing my own career in
At the time, I started deejaying.
are some of the -- I haven't done it in so long.
But when they knocked Webster Hall down, that's, like, when my deejay career basically
Webster Hall's, like, the biggest one.
But I used to do, like, little things in the city all the time.
And then, after that, I met up with Dave East's producer.
they told me to just try to do hip-hop.
I started playing shows, Webster Hall.
And I was told to -- I was doing EDM in, you know, like, the deejay scene, and
And ever since then, that's when I started doing
I've been doing hip-hop since about 2017.
I've made a ton of connections through networking, through traveling.
was in Timbaland Studio before COVID hit.
I was supposed to go to Los Angeles in 2020
to work with Chance the Rapper, but COVID happened, so I lost that opportunity.
I'm currently in the process of finalizing my trademark with the Federal
Government to have my own record label.
I currently still work with Buddha and Grinz
vocal coach is Lady Gaga and Katy Perry's vocal coach.
And I have a vocal coach, which is -- my
Did you say Dave East in the beginning?
I've met him, like, five times.
Are you at any time -- are you a veteran, for example?
Yeah, I'm a big fan of Dave East.
My family's just -- I'm, like -- I come from a family that's just -- my brother's
been in military for over 20 years.
sister's husband, he was in the Marines; he's in the Reserves now.
My brother Brian I believe did 4 years.
And so your career after high school and some community college
has been primarily in the music industry?
So let's fast-forward straight now to, you know, the lead-up to January 6th.
as we kind of discussed off the record before we started, we're interested to learn, I
guess, how you were following politics and what may have led you to want to come to
So, in general, how closely did you follow political events throughout former
To be completely honest, I didn't start paying attention to politics till COVID.
I was very busy with music.
to come true, to be completely honest.
Like I said, that year was supposed to be a very
I thought I was actually -- you know, my dreams were actually going
And then COVID happened, and I had just a ton of time on my hands.
that's kind of when I started turning into politics, to be honest.
So I'm assuming with -- are you referring to the COVID mandates that I'm
assuming forced you to have to stay in the house more?
So, during this time period, during the lockdowns, did you start,
you know, reading the news more?
Is that what kind of led to this?
I was just -- I started doing just research of just,
like, everything, to be completely honest, even, like, you know, going back just trying to
I just, like, I guess, gained an interest for just, like, America and

And I kind of saw, like, things, like, a little twisted from a sideline of things.
guess when I saw things being, like, twisted from, like, 20 years to, like, even 10 years

Do you have any questions about the research side of this?
Well, I'm just curious, Mr. Rubenacker, whether it was just, you know, the fact
that you had a lot of time, or was it, you know, the policies that were being enacted
during COVID that got you into looking into politics?
I really want to say, honestly, it was probably just the extra
Because, like, I really try not to pay attention to politics anymore, to be
completely honest, and I'm really trying to just, like, get my life back together, and I'm
really trying to tackle my dreams.
music that I've -- honestly, like, my coach is very proud of me.
And I feel like I've been making some of the best
And I've been doing music for a very long time, and I'm actually very proud of
there's so many musicians that are, you know, trying to do the same thing.
way where I think that I'm original because I make the beats.
literally everything when it comes to my songs.
And it took me a while to even be proud of myself, because, as a musician,
I write the lyrics, I perform it, I sing it, I
So, lately, I just -- I don't really have the interest anymore.
in life is I want to help people.
things that I've been through in my life.
It's always been my goal to help people because of the
You know, I lost my friends in a car accident at 18.
A year after that, I lost my
was touch and go for about a year and a half.
emotional roller coasters, you know, just never catching a break.
just dedicate my life to just putting my pain into music.
And then a year after that, my mom had a heart attack, and she
And that was probably one of the biggest
And COVID basically, I guess, yeah, just really gave me the free time.
like, I'm now really just back into doing what I do, and it's just like, I'm just trying to work
as hard as possible, and I'm trying to do the right thing as possible.
therapy; I have to check in with my probation officer.
just try to get my life back.
I really -- politics, I guess, was -- like I said, it was more because I had the time.
So it sounds like you were researching during the COVID lockdowns
But did that eventually turn into post-election news?
And when the media was -- you had one side of the media saying that the
Well, I mean, yeah, that, obviously -- you know, like I said, it came into, like,
election was completely fair, and then you had one side of the election saying that it was
And on top of that, you had a lot of Congresspeople

So, you know, it concerned me for election integrity, for sure, to see that the

So you mentioned some of the news sources and, for example, hearing what some

I guess, what channels of television, if you were watching television, were you

And that was some of the research that I did in 2020.

Like, how does someone even know something like that?

make, like, logistical sense to me.

President, and that's still how I feel.

people were very upset and very angry, you know.
